summary: This is a defense filing by Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys to Judge Alison J. Nathan, responding to the government's October 7, 2020 letter. It argues the government has failed to meet discovery obligations, including not producing the 'core' evidence from the Florida investigation, providing inadequate and unreadable materials to Maxwell in detention, and failing to provide exculpatory information. The filing criticizes the indictment's vagueness and requests court intervention.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case. Her defense attorneys argue the government has failed to provide adequate discovery and that she maintains her innocence.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case. The letter is addressed to her, requesting court orders regarding discovery and detention conditions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the central figure in the prior Florida investigation and the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) from 2007. The defense notes the discovery relates largely to him and not the charged time period.

persons.name: Jeff S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman who signed the filing. The letterhead lists him as a contact.

connections.description: The government alleges Maxwell conspired with Epstein. The defense argues discovery about Epstein from the 2000s is not relevant to the charged conspiracy period (1994-1997).
Pagliuca is one of Maxwell's defense attorneys, filing this letter on her behalf.
Nathan is the presiding judge over Maxwell's criminal case. The defense is petitioning the judge for relief regarding discovery and detention conditions.

events.title: Initial Conference / Detention Hearing
events.description: The government promised to review and produce prior investigative files from the Southern District of Florida investigation, characterizing them as part of the 'core of the case'.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA)
events.description: The government entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein. The defense states the government has not provided information about its genesis, which will form the basis of defense motions.

events.title: Government's Letter to Court
events.description: The government sent a letter to the court regarding its discovery plan, which the defense characterizes as abandoning agreed deadlines and redefining obligations.

events.title: Government Discovery Production
events.description: The government made a discovery production, but it was not made available to Maxwell at the MDC until almost three weeks later, and files were still unreadable.

events.title: Charged Conspiracy Period
events.description: The indictment alleges crimes occurred during this three-year period. The defense argues the indictment is vague and the discovery provided does not relate to this time frame.

keyFacts: The defense claims the government has failed to produce the 'core' evidence from the prior Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, which it promised at the July 2020 conference.
The defense argues the indictment is deficient because it fails to identify accusers, specific dates of alleged crimes, or exact locations, covering only the years 1994-1997.

The defense states the government has not produced exculpatory evidence, including information that dozens of women who accused Epstein did not implicate Maxwell, and details about meetings between accusers' lawyers and the government in 2016.

The filing details significant problems with Maxwell's access to discovery while detained at the MDC, including receiving productions late, files being unreadable, and restrictive visitation rules hindering attorney-client collaboration.

The defense implies the government's case rests almost exclusively on claims of three unidentified accusers, with no corroborating documentation or witness statements specifically implicating Maxwell in the alleged acts.
